seg-source.mrk: AVG function

target.mrk: AVG function

trans-unit.source: AVG is an aggregate function that evaluates the average of an expression over a set of rows.

seg-source.mrk: AVG is an aggregate function that evaluates the average of an expression over a set of rows.

target.mrk: AVG is an aggregate function that evaluates the average of an expression over a set of rows.

seg-source.mrk: AVG aggregate function

target.mrk: AVG aggregate function

seg-source.mrk: DISTINCT

target.mrk: DISTINCT

seg-source.mrk: qualifier in AVG function

target.mrk: qualifier in AVG function

trans-unit.source: AVG is allowed only on expressions that evaluate to numeric data types.

seg-source.mrk: AVG is allowed only on expressions that evaluate to numeric data types.

target.mrk: AVG is allowed only on expressions that evaluate to numeric data types.

trans-unit.source: See <xref href="rrefsqlj33923.dita#rrefsqlj33923"></xref> for more information about these functions.

seg-source.mrk: See <xref href="rrefsqlj33923.dita#rrefsqlj33923"></xref> for more information about these functions.

target.mrk: See <xref href="rrefsqlj33923.dita#rrefsqlj33923"></xref> for more information about these functions.

seg-source.mrk: Syntax

target.mrk: Syntax

seg-source.mrk: AVG ( [ DISTINCT | ALL ] expression )

target.mrk: AVG ( [ DISTINCT | ALL ] expression )

trans-unit.source: The DISTINCT qualifier eliminates duplicates. The ALL qualifier retains duplicates. ALL is the default value if neither ALL nor DISTINCT is specified. For example, if a column contains the values 1.0, 1.0, 1.0, 1.0, and 2.0, AVG(col) returns a smaller value than AVG(DISTINCT col).

seg-source.mrk: The DISTINCT qualifier eliminates duplicates.
The ALL qualifier retains duplicates.
ALL is the default value if neither ALL nor DISTINCT is specified.
For example, if a column contains the values 1.0, 1.0, 1.0, 1.0, and 2.0, AVG(col) returns a smaller value than AVG(DISTINCT col).

target.mrk: The DISTINCT qualifier eliminates duplicates.
The ALL qualifier retains duplicates.
ALL is the default value if neither ALL nor DISTINCT is specified.
For example, if a column contains the values 1.0, 1.0, 1.0, 1.0, and 2.0, AVG(col) returns a smaller value than AVG(DISTINCT col).

trans-unit.source: Only one DISTINCT aggregate expression per selectExpression is allowed. For example, the following query is not valid:

seg-source.mrk: Only one DISTINCT aggregate expression per selectExpression is allowed.
For example, the following query is not valid:

target.mrk: Only one DISTINCT aggregate expression per selectExpression is allowed.
For example, the following query is not valid:

trans-unit.source: SELECT AVG (DISTINCT flying_time), SUM (DISTINCT miles) FROM Flights

seg-source.mrk: SELECT AVG (DISTINCT flying_time), SUM (DISTINCT miles) FROM Flights

target.mrk: SELECT AVG (DISTINCT flying_time), SUM (DISTINCT miles) FROM Flights

trans-unit.source: The expression can contain multiple column references or expressions, but it cannot contain another aggregate or subquery. It must evaluate to an SQL-92 numeric data type. You can therefore call methods that evaluate to SQL-92 data types. If an expression evaluates to NULL, the aggregate skips that value.

seg-source.mrk: The expression can contain multiple column references or expressions, but it cannot contain another aggregate or subquery.
It must evaluate to an SQL-92 numeric data type.
You can therefore call methods that evaluate to SQL-92 data types.
If an expression evaluates to NULL, the aggregate skips that value.

target.mrk: The expression can contain multiple column references or expressions, but it cannot contain another aggregate or subquery.
It must evaluate to an SQL-92 numeric data type.
You can therefore call methods that evaluate to SQL-92 data types.
If an expression evaluates to NULL, the aggregate skips that value.

trans-unit.source: The resulting data type is the same as the expression on which it operates (it will never overflow). The following query, for example, returns the INTEGER 1, which might not be what you would expect:

seg-source.mrk: The resulting data type is the same as the expression on which it operates (it will never overflow).
The following query, for example, returns the INTEGER 1, which might not be what you would expect:

target.mrk: The resulting data type is the same as the expression on which it operates (it will never overflow).
The following query, for example, returns the INTEGER 1, which might not be what you would expect:

seg-source.mrk: SELECT AVG(c1) FROM (VALUES (1), (1), (1), (1), (2)) AS myTable (c1)

target.mrk: SELECT AVG(c1) FROM (VALUES (1), (1), (1), (1), (2)) AS myTable (c1)

trans-unit.source: CAST the expression to another data type if you want more precision:

seg-source.mrk: CAST the expression to another data type if you want more precision:

target.mrk: CAST the expression to another data type if you want more precision:

trans-unit.source: SELECT AVG(CAST (c1 AS DOUBLE PRECISION)) FROM (VALUES (1), (1), (1), (1), (2)) AS myTable (c1)

seg-source.mrk: SELECT AVG(CAST (c1 AS DOUBLE PRECISION)) FROM (VALUES (1), (1), (1), (1), (2)) AS myTable (c1)

target.mrk: SELECT AVG(CAST (c1 AS DOUBLE PRECISION)) FROM (VALUES (1), (1), (1), (1), (2)) AS myTable (c1)
